conversion process for production of aromatics 1.2 Scope of this review 2 Reaction pathways and structures of monometallic Mo catalysts in methane dehydroaromatization – what is known and current gaps in knowledge 3 Mo-based multifunctional methane dehydroaromatization catalysts 3.1 Transition metals leading to structured carbon deposits (Fe, Co, Ni) 3.2 Metals with higher capacity to hydrogenate carbon deposits and increase stability (Pt, Rh, Pd, Ir, Ru, Cu, W) 3.3 Metals affecting acidity of the catalyst (Cr, Ag, Ga) 4 Emerging trends with other non-Mo based multifunctional methane dehydroaromatization catalysts 4.1 Fe-based catalysts 4.2 Pt-based catalyst 5 Process intensification of methane dehydroaromatization 5.1 Absorptive H2 scavenging 5.2 Coupling with chemical looping Fig. 1 Thermodynamic equilibrium values (at P =1 bar) for (a) methane conversion and (b) product selectivity, as a function of temperature in non-oxidative methane aromatization. Calculations performed with Aspen Plus V10. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Schematics representing the two proposed reaction pathways for methane dehydroaromatization on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts: (a) bifunctional mechanism where MoCx species activate and cause CH4 coupling to C2Hx species, and Brønsted acid sites in the zeolite channels catalyze aromatization of C2Hx; (d) hydrocarbon pool-like mechanism where carbon deposits are formed during the induction period and gradually form a hydrocarbon pool leading to the autocatalytic formation of aromatics. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Formation rate of benzene over Fe (nano)-5%Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts; (b) H2-TPR proﬁles of 5%Mo/HZSM-5 and nano-Fe modified 5% Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts [(a) 5%Mo/HZSM-5, (b) 0.25 %Fe(nano)-5% Mo/HZSM-5, (c) 0.5 %Fe(nano)-5%Mo/HZSM-5, (d) 1.0 %Fe(nano)- 5%Mo/HZSM-5, (e) 1.5 %Fe(nano)-5%Mo/HZSM-5]; (c) CH4-TPSR proﬁles of 5%Mo/HZSM-5 and nano-Fe modified 5%Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. Adapted with permission from ref. [67]. Copyright 2017, American Chemical Society. A critical literature review of the advances in methane dehydroaromatization over multifunctional metal-promoted zeolite catalysts Unmesh Menon Mustafizur Rahman Sheima J. Khatib * Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, USA Department of Chemical Engineering Texas Tech University Lubbock TX 79409 USA Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas 79409, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The drastic rise in shale gas production has encouraged the quest for alternative uses of methane as a chemical feedstock in the manufacturing industry. While two-step syngas routes for methane valorization are deployed commercially, direct one-step routes for methane conversion are attracting much attention. As steam cracking installations have shifted from using oil-based naphtha to shale-based natural gas liquids, production of aromatics has dropped. Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a one-step reaction capable of valorizing methane to hydrogen and benzene. Challenges with the MDA reaction are two-fold: the reaction is thermodynamically limited with low one-pass methane conversion and even the best catalytic systems, Mo/zeolites, suffer rapid deactivation from coking. A catalyst design strategy to improve stability is the use of multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite systems where X is a dopant capable of modulating the stability. In this paper we provide a complete overview of the main Mo-X/zeolite systems used in MDA and critically draw connections among the different types of dopants (X) employed, as a function of the role they play in the reaction/deactivation pathway. We have also dedicated a section to emerging trends with non-Mo based catalysts. The goal of this review article is to establish a basis that will facilitate the identification of useful multifunctional catalytic systems, and recognize gaps in the knowledge of these systems that deserve more attention. Improving MDA systems to the point to which they can be commercially deployed requires a multifaceted approach that combines optimization of the designs of both the catalyst and the reactor configuration. We therefore also provide a brief overview of the most recent advances in process intensification strategies employed with different reactor configurations. Keywords Multifunctional Methane Dehydroaromatization Reactors 1 Introduction 1.1 Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA), a direct methane conversion process for production of aromatics For decades fluid catalytic cracking of naphtha, light diesel and other oil fractions has been the main method employed for production of hydrocarbon building blocks such as light olefins (ethylene, propylene, butene) and aromatics (BTX). But over the past decade technological advances in hydraulic fracturing have enabled a large rise in production of shale gas with subsequent drops in prices of this resource, resulting in a shift towards the use of lighter hydrocarbons as feedstocks for the production of light olefins [1,2]. Consequently, many steam cracking installations have shifted from using oil-based naphtha to shale-based natural gas liquids. Transitioning to lighter feedstocks in stream cracking results in a more cost-effective and energy-efficient means of producing specific light olefins with high selectivities, but the production of aromatic byproducts occurring in naphtha steam cracking is lost. This has resulted in a gap in production of aromatics which is currently being filled in the US by importing aromatics to meet current demands. The shift to production of lighter olefins using shale-derived hydrocarbon feedstocks has also led to a significantly higher loss of carbon to the atmosphere as a result of flaring (CO2) and gas leaks (CH4). It is estimated that 28 Bn ft3 of methane are emitted per day as a result of leaks [3], part of which are flared to produce CO2, which is a less potent greenhouse gas compared to methane. Particularly in the US, 13 million metric tonnes of methane are leaked yearly [4,5]. This is a great waste of an otherwise valuable natural resource. Not to mention the harmful environmental impact tied to the emission of such a large quantity of greenhouse gases. Converting even a small fraction of this leaked gas to aromatics would already close the demand gap for aromatics in the US, while utilizing a cheap resource. Such a conversion to aromatics from methane is possible via the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction. [6 CH4 (g) → C6H6 (g) + 9 H2 (g)] This reaction is non-oxidative, requires no reagents, and happens directly in one step, placing it at an advantage for methane utilization compared to syngas processes that valorize methane in multiple steps. Furthermore, the directness of the process allows for a modular design of the process and offers the possibility of on-shore production of valuable aromatics. There are however several drawbacks that are currently preventing commercial deployment of MDA. On one hand the reaction is limited by its thermodynamics: the reaction is endothermic ( Δ G r 0 = 104 k c a l ∙ m o l - 1 ; Δ H r 0 = 127 k c a l ∙ m o l - 1 ) , requiring high reaction temperature and at 700 °C the thermodynamic equilibrium conversion of methane is around 12 % [6,7] thus yielding relatively small amounts of benzene. Furthermore, the formation of coke in reaction is drastically high and is considered the main cause of rapid catalyst deactivation. Thermodynamic equilibrium values of methane conversion and product selectivities in non-oxidative MDA are presented as a function of temperature in Fig. 1 . Zeolites modified with metals such as W [8–15], Re [16–18], Fe [19–21], Ru [22], and Cr [23] are to a certain extent active in MDA, but the most efficient and commonly studied catalysts are Mo-modified ZSM-5 (Mo/ZSM-5) materials. Much effort has been dedicated over the three past decades towards finding strategies to improve single-pass methane conversion and catalyst stability using zeolite supported Mo catalysts. These can broadly be divided into process intensification strategies and catalyst design strategies. Process intensification routes involve reactor design methods capable of shifting CH4 conversion above the thermodynamic equilibrium conversion and/or reducing the effects of coking by regeneration. Several review papers enumerate these strategies [24–30]; therefore, in the final sections of this review we will briefly summarize them and comment on the most recent advances on this topic. Catalyst design strategies are key in achieving structural stability, and can have a high impact on enabling the deployment of MDA since coking is a ubiquitous problem that remains prevalent even when the thermodynamic barrier is broken using process intensification methods. A recent progress report [31] analyzes the most relevant catalyst design strategies pursued to date to improve catalyst stability, which generally consist in engineering the properties, distribution, and location of the Mo species, or engineering the textural and acidic properties of the zeolite support in the Mo/ZSM-5 system. One strategy however has not been reviewed in detail to date: that of promoting Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts by addition of a second metal. 1.2 Scope of this review Multiple studies have demonstrated that when Mo/zeolite catalysts are modified by incorporating a second metal, catalyst stability is improved. But the choice of the dopants seemed to be based more on trial and error. A systematic study of the effect of the promoters is lacking. Our main goal in this paper is to summarize in one place the literature on Mo-based MDA catalysts where a second metal dopant has been introduced to strategically improve the catalyst stability. Much of the MDA literature on multifunctional Mo-based catalysts seems disconnected, with no clear account on structure-activity relationships. Our aim is to provide the reader with a complete overview of the main Mo-X (X = dopant) systems used in MDA and critically draw connections among the different types of dopants employed, as a function of the role they play in the reaction/deactivation pathway. The intent is to, in this way, establish a basis that will facilitate the identification of useful Mo-X systems, and recognize gaps in their knowledge that deserve more attention. Given the promotional role of the second metals, it is important to keep in mind the recent advances in research of monometallic Mo/zeolite catalysts in MDA. Multiple excellent reviews on monometallic Mo catalysts have been published in the recent years [24,27,29–38], therefore here we will only provide a brief overview on the most important recent findings related to monometallic Mo/zeolite catalysts to set the basis for the rest of the review. We will then provide a critical review focused on research on multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite catalysts in MDA. We will dedicate a short section on non-Mo based catalysts that have recently been emerging in the literature. Finally, we will briefly review the most encouraging process intensification advances in MDA, which can potentially be explored in combination with multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite catalysts to provide enhanced production of aromatics. 2 Reaction pathways and structures of monometallic Mo catalysts in methane dehydroaromatization – what is known and current gaps in knowledge To begin to understand the promotional role that a second metal plays in Mo-based catalysts, it is important to consider the current status of the research regarding the reaction mechanism, and the structure and location of the Mo species in monometallic Mo catalysts during the different reaction stages. This information will facilitate understanding the role that a second metal can play in multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite systems. Catalytic materials consisting of Mo species supported on ZSM-5 and MCM-22 zeolites present the best performance in MDA, reaching methane conversions up to 14 % and benzene selectivity as high as 80 %. The MDA reaction mechanism has not been fully determined, but it is commonly accepted that the reaction goes through three stages consisting of activation/induction, dehydroaromatization (formation of aromatics), and deactivation. The two main reaction mechanisms that have been proposed consist of the bifunctional mechanism and the hydrocarbon pool mechanism. Schematics of these mechanisms are shown in Fig. 2 . The bifunctional mechanism has historically been the most broadly cited in the literature and is explained based on the bifunctionality of the Mo/zeolite catalysts, with Mo and Brønsted acid sites (BAS) playing different roles in the reaction pathway. In the as-prepared catalyst Mo oxide species are anchored to the zeolite support via oxygen bridges at the BAS and upon exposure to the methane reactant, they are reduced and carburized to form Mo oxycarbide and carbide species. These reduced species are considered responsible for activating methane and facilitating its conversion to C2Hx molecules. But the exact structure and degree of reduction of the actual active Mo moieties remains under debate. The C2 fragments then undergo oligomerization and aromatization on the BAS of the zeolite support, leading to formation of benzene. The aromatic molecules thus formed can condense further as they encounter more BAS as they diffuse within the zeolite channel, forming larger polyaromatic molecules, which, due to their size, are incapable of escaping the zeolite structure and eventually form highly dehydrogenated polyaromatic carbon deposits or coke which causes pore blocking and consequent catalyst deactivation. The most commonly employed zeolite support, ZSM-5, possesses a channel diameter that is similar to the kinetic diameter of benzene (∼ 5 Å), which confers the catalyst with product shape selectivity and can explain its superior selectivity compared to other zeolites with pores that are smaller or larger than ten member rings. The hydrocarbon-pool mechanism has been gaining more traction recently, having been proposed as a result of studies showing that Mo carbide species within confined spaces, and in the absence of BAS, such as in Mo/Silicalite-1 catalyst, are capable of producing aromatics [39,40]. Using pulsing reaction techniques in combination with spectroscopy and microscopy characterization, the Hensen group observed that carbon deposition was taking place in the catalyst as early as during the induction period. Analysis of the nature of the carbon confined in the zeolite channels demonstrated that it was polyaromatic with radical character [41,42]. Furthermore, their isotopic studies verified that the carbon that was deposited in the induction period appeared in the benzene products formed in the dehydroaromatization stage. Similar conclusions were reached by Vollmer et al. [43,44]. These results suggested that the confined hydrocarbon species could play a role similar to those of confined organocatalytic intermediates in the methanol-to-hydrocarbon reactions. Further characterization and kinetic studies would be required to acquire a clearer picture of the exact reaction intermediates for both mechanisms, but thus far, both mechanisms seem to be possible and their coexistence cannot be discarded. Within this context, a very recent study by Gascon and contributors [45] employed advanced MAS-NMR measurements in different stages of reaction and verified the presence of several reaction intermediates including methylidene, surface methoxy species, surface formate species, acetal, all of which suggest that during the early stages of reaction both monofunctional and bifunctional routes could coexist. They state that these intermediates eventual lead to the formation of a hydrocarbon pool. Via thermochemical kinetic analyses and counting of Mo and BAS sites at different stages of reaction, Bhan and coworkers showed that, only the Mo sites catalyze the rate controlling steps in MDA, suggesting that the Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts are in fact monofunctional [46] and that while the BAS may be catalytically active, are not kinetically relevant. This conclusion is in agreement with the results obtained with Mo/Silicalite-1 catalysts, showing formation of benzene in absence of BAS [39,40]. How exactly methane is activated on the Mo species has not been fully resolved. On one hand, it is thought that activation of methane occurs on the Mo site, and that the electronic modification experienced by reduced Mo in the carbide structure allows Mo to act like a noble metal capable of abstracting hydrogen from methane. This process aligns well with DFT calculations that show that methane activates preferentially over Mo-C than on Mo-O [47]. On the other hand, there are isotopic studies that suggest that the carbon on the catalyst surface itself is involved in the reaction mechanism [43] and plays a similar role to oxygen in oxide catalysts that function via the Mars van Krevelen mechanism. Yet another possible activation mechanism that has been proposed consists of the involvement of the BAS in the hydrogen abstraction of methane. In this case, a close proximity of the Mo and BAS is necessary so that when the Mo abstracts hydrogen from the methane molecule, the resulting CH3 + can form a methoxy species by interacting with the oxygen at the neighboring BAS. This methoxy then reacts with another CH4 molecule to form C2Hxspecies. This mechanism would agree with findings by Kosinov et al. [39] who demonstrated that when the two functionalities, that of Mo and BAS, were separated aromatization did not occur. The identity of the C2Hx molecule as ethylene or acetylene remains a subject of debate given that acetylene is an unstable molecule under the reaction conditions and thus not easily detectable. Recently Razdan et al. proposed that in fact the initial product resulting from CC coupling is ethane [46] which then converts to ethylene and acetylene. The C2Hx molecule then polymerizes to form larger hydrocarbons and eventually aromatics. All these findings suggest that the role of the zeolite BAS in MDA catalysts can be multiple: (1) most importantly they provide anchoring points for the Mo oxides inside the zeolite channels, allowing for a good dispersion and appropriate location for the active sites which will enable product shape selectivity to benzene; (2) they could be involved in oligomerization of C2 species to benzene and larger aromatics according to the bifunctional mechanism; (3) they are possibly involved in activating methane by assisting hydrogen abstraction. As for the structure, the catalyst precursor consists of fully oxidized Mo species that are anchored to the zeolite framework via oxygen bridges. Researchers have placed great effort into determining the location and structure of these oxides, reaching different conclusions. The discrepancy in results is likely due to the differences in synthesis methods and conditions used to support the Mo oxide on the zeolite (incipient wetness impregnation with Mo salt precursors followed by calcination, versus physical mixing of MoO3 and calcination), different Si/Al ratios of the zeolites employed, and different Mo loadings, to mention a few. Iglesia and coworkers demonstrated that each Mo ion replaces one proton inside the ZSM-5 channels, forming MoO2(OH)+ which eventually condense to form Mo2O5 2+ species with ditetrahedral structure [48]. Other research groups [49] have encountered different Mo structures based on their location in the zeolite, with Mo species associated to Al sites inside the channels and MoO3 crystallites and MoOx with square-pyramidal coordination on the external surface of the zeolite. Wachs and Podkolzin [50] combined experimental spectroscopic techniques with theoretical chemical DFT calculations and found that at low Mo loadings (0.7–3.3 wt% Mo) the active Mo species were isolated single Mo oxide species anchored onto single and two-atom Al sites inside the zeolite channels, but on the external zeolite channel they were anchored onto the Si sites. Liu et al. were able to observe isolated Mo oxide species inside the zeolite channels via integrated differential phase-contrast scanning transmission electron microscopy [51]. Whether the structure and type of bonding of the Mo oxide (monomeric oxides versus dimeric or polymeric oxides) plays a role in the catalytic activity is not clear since the oxides eventually reduce and carburize transforming into the active sites. In situ studies on this transformation have concluded that the Mo oxide species are first reduced to Mo oxycarbides and then to carbides, at which point it is thought that the Mo species detach from the zeolite framework. Using in situ X-Ray Absorption (XAS) measurements both the Iglesia [52,53] and Wachs-Podkolzin [47] research groups identified the carbide formed to be the more stable carbide, β-Mo2C, Meanwhile the Beale research group [54] employing Operando X-Ray methods concluded that after the induction period the carbide stoichiometry was closer to Mo1.6C3. They recently observed, by means of XAS Operando techniques, that when Mo oxycarbides are formed, no aromatics are produced and only when a fully carburized Mo1.6C3 species appears, are benzene and other aromatics detected. An important point made by all these researchers is that once the Mo carbides are formed, they detach from the O anchoring sites and seem to have the capacity to move within the zeolite channel. When Kosinov et al. [42] studied the structure of the Mo species in Mo/ZSM-5 with different Mo loadings (using XANES, TGA, and XPS) in quasi-operando mode using a pulse reaction technique and isotope labelling, they reached similar findings for higher Mo loadings, however, at lower Mo loading (1 wt%) they actually found that benzene was formed when Mo species were only partially reduced and still anchored to the ZSM-5 framework. Vollmer et al. [55] employed quasi-in situ spectroscopic techniques including 13C-NMR and COIR to study the evolution of the Mo species in MDA by previously carburizing them in CO. They distinguished two types of Mo species within the zeolite channels and Mo clusters on the external surface and they assigned the activity of the catalysts to the oxycarbide species that were formed inside the channels. The results from both these groups seem to be in accord with their proposed hydrocarbon pool mechanism for MDA. Analysis of the structure of the spent catalysts points to several causes for deactivation, but the most significant one is coking. Deactivation usually is a result of pore blockage, which is mostly due to deposition of coke. But aggregation of Mo species during the induction period [56],when Mo oxide species with low Tamman temperature are more mobile [48], and collapse of the zeolite structure, due to the extraction of framework Al caused by Mo, can also be contributing factors to pore blockage. In the case of Al extraction by Mo, formation of inactive Al2(MoO4)3 species [57] further hinders catalyst performance. Both Mo aggregation and Al extraction by Mo can be minimized by employing low Mo contents [58]. Coking is a more difficult problem to solve because carbon formation originates from the reaction pathway and is thermodynamically the most stable product at MDA reaction conditions [6,7]. Condensation of the aromatic molecules leads to the formation of dehydrogenated polyaromatic carbon deposits that are held accountable for blocking both the zeolite channels and the active sites [41,59–61]. Various groups that have analyzed the carbon deposits formed during the reaction agree that various types of carbon structures are formed, and that not all types cause catalyst deactivation. Apart from carbidic carbon, hydrogenated pre-graphitic carbon deposits associated to the Mo sites, and highly polyaromatic carbon associated with the BAS have been identified [38,62,63]. Time and again research groups have observed that the catalyst deactivation correlates with the higher formation of the hydrogen-deficient sp-type carbon deposits associated to the BAS, and it has been proposed that zeolites with high acidity enhance the formation of this type of carbon. Matus et al. [64] detected two types of carbonaceous deposits and described them as graphite layers on the surface of Mo2C particles and disordered carbon layers associated to the zeolite surface. Beale and coworkers [54] demonstrated by in situ XAS measurements and high resolution XRD and Rietveld analysis that as reaction proceeds, the Mo carbides inside the channels migrate to the external surface where they lose product shape selectivity, leading to a drop in the formation of benzene at the expense of forming non-selective coke on the external surface. In their work with Mo/Silicalte-1 they proposed that weaker Mo carbide- support interactions in Mo/Silicalte-1 lead to higher Mo carbide mobility and higher chances of their displacement from the inner channels to the external surface [40]. Raman spectroscopic measurements displayed a higher ratio of the intensities of the D1 to G bands, for Mo/Silicalite-1 versus Mo/ZSM-5, indicating higher degree of disorder in the carbon deposits in the former. They suggested that the disordered graphitic carbon was associated to the Mo carbide species that had migrated outside of the zeolite channels and was therefore located on the external surface of the zeolite. Kosinov et al. [41] on the other hand only detected sp2 carbon of aromatic nature in their spent catalysts by 13C-NMR despite having detected peaks corresponding to both “soft” and “hard” coke in their TGA/DTG analyses. They explained the detection of the two types of carbon burning at different temperatures in the DTG analyses is a result of diffusion limitations due to the different locations of the same carbon species on the external surface and inside the zeolite channels. 3 Mo-based multifunctional methane dehydroaromatization catalysts Addition of certain metal dopants to Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts improves their catalytic performance and stability by influencing the catalyst deactivation step. Based on how this enhancement is achieved, the metal promoters used thus far can be classified into the following groups: (a) transition metals capable of changing the nature of the carbon deposits formed in reaction (Fe, Co, Ni); (b) noble metals capable of hydrogenating and removing carbon deposits as they form in reaction (Pt, Rh, Pd, Ir, Ru, Cu); (c) metals capable of affecting the acidity of Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts (Cr, Ag, Ga) and leading to higher methane conversion and benzene yield. These systems will be described in detail next, with special emphasis placed on the correlations between structural characterization of the catalysts and their activity. 3.1 Transition metals leading to structured carbon deposits (Fe, Co, Ni) Metals such as Fe, Co, and Ni are known to promote formation of carbon nanotubes in the presence of hydrocarbons. When these metals are added to Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts in MDA, they have the capacity to steer the condensation of the heavier hydrocarbons and aromatics towards forming carbon nanotubes instead of the graphitic and amorphous carbon deposits that lead to faster catalyst deactivation. In this section we will compare the results obtained by different researchers using these metals as additives in Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic data for the Fe, Co, and Ni modified catalysts discussed in this section. Table 2 presents the structural and physicochemical properties reported by the most promising catalyst compositions from this section. Masiero et al. [65] studied the effect of the Mo:Fe ratios and of the total metal loading (5−15 wt%) on the catalytic structure and activity of Mo-Fe/H-ZSM-5 catalysts. They employed wet co-impregnation of the Mo and Fe salt precursors on a ZSM-5 support with Si/Al = 15. They found an optimum bimetallic composition (Mo:Fe = 4:1) at 10 wt% total metal loading that exhibited a higher catalyst stability and benzene selectivity compared to the monometallic Mo catalyst. How the catalysts performed continuously over time was not reported in this work, and conclusions were drawn based on the activity reported at only two points in time: after the induction period (reported as the time at which maximum CH4 conversion was reached) and after 3 h of reaction. The stability of the catalysts was analyzed based on the methane conversion measured after 3 h of reaction divided by the maximum methane conversion obtained after the induction period. Catalysts containing higher Mo proportions were more active and presented higher methane conversions after the induction period, while the pure Fe catalyst hardly showed any catalytic activity. Catalysts that presented iron in their composition were generally more stable and the optimum benzene yield and stability was obtained with the catalyst with Mo:Fe = 4:1. These results suggested that the Mo species were mainly responsible for the MDA activity, whereas small amounts of Fe enhanced the catalytic performance. To characterize the structure of the fresh and spent catalysts, these authors used a combination of BET surface area measurements, X-ray diffraction (XRD), NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), temperature programmed oxidation (TPO), and thermogravimetric analysis and differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA). BET surface areas of the catalysts were used to draw conclusions regarding the dispersion of metal species. At a fixed 5% metal loading, the surface areas were higher when both metals coexisted, suggesting a higher metal dispersion when both were present. The BET surface areas of the catalysts with the optimum Mo:Fe ratio of 4:1 and different total loading (5, 10, and 15 wt%) did not show significant differences and no conclusions could be derived regarding channel occupation by the metals or their distribution between the external zeolite surface and inside the channels. While it is not clearly stated in the paper, it appears that TGA/DTA experiments were performed with the metal impregnated zeolites prior to calcination and were used to monitor the weight loss experienced by the catalysts during the calcination step. The formation of different oxide structures in the calcination step was inferred from analysis of the TGA profiles. These results indirectly suggested that there was a presence of a mixed iron molybdate phase in all the catalysts with Mo:Fe ratio of 4:1 with total metal loadings ranging from 5 to 15 wt%. The presence of this mixed phase was further demonstrated upon analysis of the XRD patterns of the samples where peaks corresponding to a Fe2(MoO4)3 phase were detected for the Mo-Fe catalysts with Mo:Fe ratio of 4:1. These peaks were however very weak and practically indistinguishable from the baseline noise. The lack of quantification of this bimetallic phase prevents us from drawing any correlation between the presence of this phase and the catalytic activity. Analysis of the acidity of the catalysts with different Mo:Fe ratios by NH3-TPD seemed to indicate that the presence of higher proportions of Fe led to a strengthening of the strong acid sites. The peak corresponding to strong acid sites was attributed to BAS and its intensity dropped slightly with Fe, suggesting a possible interaction of the Fe species with the BAS. For the catalysts with the optimum Mo:Fe ratio of 4:1 and different total metal loadings it was found that the catalyst with optimum performance in reaction (2% Fe-8%Mo) possessed acid sites which were stronger than any of the other catalysts, suggesting that this higher acidity was playing a role in the enhanced catalytic performance in MDA. TPO of the spent catalysts showed that at the lower metal loading (5 wt%) only one COx peak was detected, and this peak shifted to higher temperature when Fe was present. The authors assigned this peak at ∼450 °C to “soft” (or more hydrogenated) coke when Fe content was low. When Fe content was higher (2.5 wt%) the “soft” coke peak almost disappeared and instead a peak at higher temperature at ∼560 °C assigned to “hard” (or less hydrogenated) coke appeared which is attributed to carbon deposits formed by condensation of the aromatic molecules at the BAS of the zeolite. It was concluded that an optimum metal loading and Mo:Fe ratio lead to more stable and active catalysts and that their behavior is linked to the formation of a mixed iron molybdate phases, strengthening of the BAS and a redistribution of the types of carbon deposits formed in reaction. Abdelsayed at al. [66] prepared Mo-Fe-Zn catalysts supported on ZSM-5 using a similar synthesis procedure to Masiero at al [65]. and with similar Mo loading. They used a Si/Al ratio of 22.5 for the ZSM-5 support. As discussed earlier, the Si/Al ratio plays an important role in the capacity of the zeolite to incorporate metal species within its channels. Thus the discrepancies between their results and those of Masiero et al. [65] could be due to the different acidity of the starting ZSM-5 support. They studied catalysts with 4 wt% Mo loading, modified by 0.3 wt% Fe or/and 1 wt% Zn. The highest methane conversion and benzene formation rates were obtained with the Mo-Fe catalyst. Both the Mo-Zn and Mo-Zn-Fe catalysts showed higher benzene formation rates compared to the unmodified Mo catalyst, however, they ended up deactivating at a similar rate, while the Mo-Fe not only improved benzene formation rate by 35 % with respect to the unmodified catalyst, but also presented higher stability. They attributed the higher stability to the capacity of Fe species to steer the conversion of methane and of other hydrocarbon products towards carbon nanotubes instead of allowing them to condense into “hard” coke responsible for deactivation. The carbon nanotube structure enables more diffusion of both reactants and products which can contribute to enhanced catalytic performance. The inhibition of formation of “hard” coke in presence of Fe was corroborated by TPO and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging of the spent catalysts. In this work, no Mo-Fe mixed species were detected by any of the characterization techniques employed. Were they to exist, they would be difficult to detect directly given the low Fe loadings. To gain insight into the occupation of the zeolite channels by the metals, they analyzed the d-spacing of the zeolite X-ray diffraction peaks at low 2θ angles and found that adding Fe did not affect the space within the zeolite channels possibly due to the very low amount of Fe present. They used NH3-TPD profiles to quantify the BAS under the assumption that the high temperature peak in the profiles was representative of the BAS. These profiles indicated no change in the number of BAS after adding Fe to the Mo catalyst, further supporting that the Fe species were not interacting with the BAS in the zeolite channels. Based on these results, they concluded that the Fe species were positioned on the external surface of the zeolite and were partially blocking the zeolite channels. In agreement with Masiero et al. [65] this research group found that upon addition of Fe, the strength of the BAS increased, but how this related to the catalytic activity was not discussed. Sun et al. [67] investigated Fe modified Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts employing a slightly different synthesis method from the previous studies. Instead of adding both metals to ZSM-5 by the incipient wetness co-impregnation, they prepared 5 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts by impregnation and calcination, and subsequently mixed these catalysts with iron nanoparticles via ball milling. Fe loadings ranging from 0.25 to 1.5 wt% Fe were tested. All the Fe-modified catalysts presented higher methane conversion values compared to the Mo catalyst within the first five hours of reaction, but no specific trend related to the Fe loading was observed within this time (see Fig. 3 (a)). After five hours, the conversion values were more distinguishable, with methane conversion rates rising with Fe loading up to a maximum of 1 wt% Fe and then dropping for 1.5 wt% Fe. This requirement of an optimum Fe loading was similar to what Masiero et al. [65] had observed. The Fe-modified catalysts deactivated at a slower rate than the unmodified Mo catalyst. The catalyst with 0.25 wt% Fe maintained the highest rate of formation of benzene for the first 10 h of reaction, but then deactivated fast and by 20 h presented no improvement compared to the unmodified catalyst, yielding similar amount of aromatics and deactivating at the same rate. On the other hand, the catalysts with 1 and 1.5 wt% Fe showed enhanced benzene formation rates compared to the unmodified Mo catalyst, but the enhancement was not as high as with the 0.25 wt% Fe catalysts. The advantage with these catalysts was that they maintained their enhanced benzene yield with respect to the unmodified catalyst for the entire 50 h of reaction. Thus, it was concluded that addition of optimum amounts of Fe was necessary to improve both the benzene yield and stability of the Mo catalyst. Control tests run with only Fe and Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts indicated that these are not selective to the formation of aromatics, producing only H2, C2 and coke at 700 °C, leading to the conclusion that a synergy was established when both metals coexisted. To understand how the structure of the modified catalysts could be causing this effect, they performed textural analysis, XRD characterization, NH3-TPD, pyridine Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CH4 temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR), TGA and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of the catalysts. They found that both the BET surface area and the micropore volume decreased upon addition of the different amounts of Fe, indicating that some Fe could be entering the zeolite channels and interacting with the Mo, but they concluded that most of the Fe was deposited in fact on the external surface of the zeolite. The acidity studies by NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR further supported that addition of Fe decreased the amount of both BAS and Lewis acid sites. Analysis of the NH3-TPD profiles led the authors to conclude that most of the Fe was interacting with the BAS on the external surface of the zeolite. But based on the FTIR data it is difficult to discard the fact that Fe could be entering the zeolite channels and potentially interacting with the Mo species located there. The XRD patterns only showed features corresponding to the ZSM-5 support and no metal oxide phases were detected, indicating that the Mo oxide was well dispersed on the support and no bimetallic phases were formed. The H2-TPR results indicated that the first Mo reduction peak corresponding to the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 shifted to lower temperature in the presence of Fe (see Fig. 3 (b)) and this effect was explained by H2 spillover caused by activation and dissociation of the H2 molecules on the Fe sites. Similarly, when they monitored the CO signal resulting from the reduction of the Mo oxide to Mo carbide via CH4-TPSR of the fresh catalysts, they found that it shifted to lower temperature in the presence of Fe (Fig. 3 (c)). While the authors did not comment on the effect of the Fe loading, an examination of the TPSR profiles shows the presence of a trend where lower Fe loading actually led to a larger shift of the CO peak to lower temperature. In other words, it seems that the catalyst with 0.25 % Fe was the easiest to reduce, coinciding also with the fact that it presented the highest rate of formation of benzene within the first 10 h of reaction. The catalysts with higher Fe loadings also presented higher reducibility and better ability to form Mo carbide in the presence of methane, which would explain their improved performance compared to the unmodified Mo catalyst. The TGA profiles of the spent catalysts showed that in fact the presence of Fe led to an increase in the total amount of carbon deposited in reaction, but they did not mention any distinctions between “soft” and “hard” coke as other researchers have. Imaging of the spent catalysts clearly showed the presence of carbon nanotubes, and further supported that the higher the loading of Fe, the more carbon nanotubes were discerned in the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Fig. 4 ). They concluded that Fe promotes the formation of carbon nanotubes and that this process probably competes with other carbon formation pathways that would otherwise lead to the formation of deactivating coke deposits on the external surface and at the channel openings of the zeolites. These conclusions aligned well with those of Abdelsayed et al. [66]. The TEM images showed that several carbon nanotubes seemed to grow out of Fe particles located on the surface of the zeolite particles (Fig. 5 ). It is known that Fe species are effective for the growth of carbon nanotubes [68,69]. Thus, they speculated that both Fe and Mo-Fe alloys on the external surface could be responsible for polycondensation of formed aromatics to carbon nanotubes once they diffused out of the zeolite channel. The carbon nanotubes present a kinetic diameter of approximately 10 Å which would allow both the diffusion of methane to the active sites and the diffusion of the benzene product out of the channel. They also speculated that the presence of carbon nanotubes could prevent agglomeration of the zeolite particles, which would also enhance the stability of the catalysts over time. They ran a control test where they mixed carbon nanotubes with Mo/ZSM-5 in the reactor bed and found enhanced catalytic performance, both in methane conversion, benzene yield and catalyst stability. No results from these experiments were specifically presented in the paper though. The authors suggested the possibility of formation of Mo-Fe alloys that led to carbon nanotube formation. This speculation could be extended to the Fe2(MoO4)3 phases obtained by Masiero et al. [65] which in reaction may have reduced to form similar alloys. Further in situ characterization of these catalysts would be necessary to confirm the presence of such phases after the induction period. Xu et al. [68,70] studied the effect of Fe on 5 wt% Mo on ZSM-5 screening Fe loadings varying within the range of 0.3–2 wt%. They observed improved benzene yield and catalyst stability in presence of Fe. Higher benzene yield was obtained for an optimum Fe loading of 0.5 wt%, but catalyst stability was better at higher Fe loading of 1 wt%. This effect of higher stability with higher Fe content, as well as these optimum catalyst compositions are similar to the ones noted by Sun et al. [67] despite the fact that the synthesis methods employed were significantly different. While Sun et al. [67] directly mixed metallic Fe nanoparticles with previously impregnated Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts, Xu et al. [70] employed a co-impregnation of Mo and Fe salt precursor solutions. Minimal structural characterization of the fresh catalysts was provided in this paper, but the authors concluded that the Fe species were located on the external surface of the zeolite based only on their NH3-TPD profiles. These profiles presented a different behavior compared to the other papers, including that of Sun et al. [67]. Here, Xu et al. found that addition of Fe resulted in an increase in the area under the high temperature peak that they assigned to the BAS, and they concluded that not only were the Fe species not interacting with the BAS, but they were also preventing Mo from migrating into the zeolite channels. To better comprehend the effect of Fe on catalyst stability, they characterized the spent catalysts by TPO and SEM imaging. The TPO profiles showed that in absence of Fe, the spent Mo catalyst only presented one COx peak (similar to the single-peak profile observed by Masiero et al. [65]), and upon addition of Fe, a second peak appeared at higher temperature and its intensity increased with Fe loading. In this work the two peaks reported appear at around 500 and 615 °C which are slightly higher temperatures than those reported by Masiero et al. [65] and Abdelsayed et al. [66] but this difference could simply be due to different experimental conditions. Their SEM images indicate that all the Fe-modified catalysts presented carbon nanotubes and the diameter of these nanotubes became larger with Fe content, correlating with the increase in the intensity of the high temperature peak (615 °C) with Fe loading. The authors concluded that this peak corresponded to the carbon nanotubes. Masiero et al. [65] had also observed an increase in the area under the high temperature peak with Fe loading, whereas Abdelsayed et al. [66] observed an opposite trend, with a drop in the high temperature peak intensity in presence of Fe and which they assigned to “hard” coke. The cause for this discrepancy is unclear but it could be that they only reported the signal corresponding to CO2, while the others were reporting signals detected for both CO2 and CO. The authors speculated the following possible mechanisms for the promotion of Fe: (a) Fe catalyzed the growth of carbon nanotubes at the expense of formation of deactivating coke by consuming CHx intermediates, as well as benzene and naphthalene that would otherwise condense to form this type of coke; (b) the presence of carbon nanotubes could prevent agglomeration of nanosized zeolite particles to microsized ones, promoting inter-crystalline molecular diffusion and possibly less formation of coke deposits, as aromatics would diffuse through the void spaces between zeolite crystals before condensing [67]; and (c) the presence of Fe could dissociate H2 and lead to coke removal via hydrogenation (C + H2 = CH4) [52,71]. Similar structural conclusions were obtained by Cheng et al. [72] when they studied Mo-Fe catalysts, although the behavior of the catalysts in reaction cannot be compared since they employed CO2 cofeeds in the reaction. Recently, Sridhar et al. [73] approached the MDA catalysts in a slightly different manner by placing importance on the conditions in which the catalysts were pretreated. Most of the published literature preheated the catalysts in He up to reaction temperature and then switched to methane flow at high temperature, at which point the oxide precursors were carburized during an induction period under methane flow. Sridhar et al. explored pretreating the catalyst by using a slow temperature ramp and flowing a dilute mixture of methane in hydrogen (CH4:H2 = 1:11). They found that when 6 wt% Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts were pretreated in He, addition of 0.2 wt% Fe slightly improved the benzene yield, but not the catalyst stability. Higher loadings of Fe were detrimental. But when catalysts were pre-reduced before reaching reaction temperature, in presence of 0.2 wt% Fe both benzene yield and catalyst stability were enhanced (Fig. 6 ). They concluded that apart from determining the optimum loading of Fe, it is important to also factor in the type of pretreatment employed. Under pretreatment in reducing conditions, aggregation of Mo oxides is minimized as the oxides are reduced at lower temperatures [74,75]. As with other groups, they also observed that more carbon nanotubes were formed with higher Fe loadings but they related the higher catalyst stability to a generally lower carbon content. The location of the metals was not analyzed, but TPR experiments indicated that the presence of Fe enhanced the reducibility of Mo and therefore they speculated that Mo carbide species were formed more easily in the presence of Fe. Aboul-Gheit et al. [76] compared catalysts containing 6 wt% Mo with modified catalysts containing 3 wt% Fe and 3 wt% Mo using H-ZSM-5 with Si/Al = 25. These catalysts presented lower catalytic performance, clearly showing that the relatively heavy Fe loading in these catalysts did not pose any synergistic effects, further underpinning the importance of maintaining low Fe loadings in Mo-Fe catalysts in order to obtain synergy in MDA. When Burns et al. [77] studied Mo-Fe catalysts prior to any of the other groups, they reported kinetic results without providing any structural characterization of their catalysts. They employed 3 wt% Mo and a 0.25:1 atomic ratio of Fe:Mo. In order to understand the kinetics, they measured not only the rate of formation of benzene but also the rate of formation of H2. They used the H2:C6H6 formation rate ratio to understand the effect that the metals could have on the evolution of different reaction pathways. If the sole products of reaction were benzene and H2, then this ratio would be equivalent to 9. However, they found this was not the case for most catalysts, suggesting therefore the presence of side reactions. They found that in the unpromoted Mo catalyst, this ratio remained more or less stable within the 20–25 range (a value that further suggested the formation of coke as a reaction product). In the case of the Mo-Fe catalyst, this ratio initially increased with reaction time, reaching a sharp maximum after one hour and then dropped gradually. This behavior suggested that when Fe was present the rate of side reactions responsible for formation of H2 and coke was higher at the beginning of reaction, and in time decreased compared to the rate of reactions responsible for formation of benzene. Overall, the values in the presence of Fe were higher than that of the unmodified Mo catalyst indicating that the presence of Fe accelerated the formation of carbon deposits. They performed elemental analysis of the catalysts after reaction to determine the C/H ratio of the carbon deposits and found that the carbon content for the catalyst containing Fe was higher, 5.69 %, compared to the unmodified Mo catalyst, 4.21 %, while the hydrogen content in both was almost the same (0.14 and 0.15 % for Mo-Fe and Mo respectively). This suggested that upon addition of the Fe, the coke deposits formed were richer in carbon. They speculated that the higher stability of the Fe-containing catalysts could be due to either retardation of the coke deposition, or formation of new active bimetallic species as the reaction progressed. No structural characterization was provided to prove these points their results agree however with the Fe-promoted formation of carbon nanotubes. When Liu et al. [78] studied Mo catalysts modified with Fe and with Co, they made similar speculations in regards to the formation of bimetallic species to explain the enhanced benzene yield and catalyst stability. However, they too did not provide any structural characterization that could evidence the existence of the bimetallic phase. They further emphasized that lower concentrations of the metal modifiers led to higher benzene yield enhancements and suggested an optimum atomic ratio of X/(X + Mo) = 0.2−0.4 for X = Fe, Co when using catalysts with 3 wt% Mo. The effect of Ni additive on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts in MDA was evaluated by Vosmerikov et al. [79]. They prepared the catalysts using a similar synthesis procedure to Sun et al. [67]. They mixed nanosized Mo and Ni particles with ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 20) employing ball milling procedure. They used a fixed Mo loading of 4 wt% and varying Ni loadings from 0.1–2 wt%. The state of the Mo and Ni precursors was not specified, and it is unclear whether they were mixed in their metallic or oxidized form. While the synthesis procedure describes the production of the Ni and Mo nanoparticles via explosion of nanowires, the authors refer to the metals as being oxides in the fresh catalysts. It could be that these metals were oxidized during the calcination step if it is assumed that this step was carried out in air. This too was not specified in the article and therefore the reproduction of their results can be challenging. The catalysts with high Ni loadings (1 and 2 wt% Ni) did not show improvements in methane conversion or catalyst stability compared to the unmodified Mo catalyst. But, as in the case of Fe, doping lower Ni content resulted in higher activity and longer catalyst life. Specifically, with addition of 0.1 wt% of Ni the benzene yield improved with respect to the unmodified catalyst and remained high for a longer period of time. While addition of 0.2 and 0.5 wt% Ni did not improve the benzene yield, the catalysts were still more stable than the unmodified catalyst. The NH3-TPD profiles of all the catalysts indicated that addition of Ni resulted in a decrease in the total amount of acid sites, as well as a drop in the concentration of stronger acid sites. While not concretely mentioned by the authors, this drop suggests that some Ni could interacting with the BAS inside the zeolite channels which could lead to higher proximity and consequent interaction with the Mo species located inside the channels. As Ni content increased to 1 and 2 wt%, additional high temperature peaks were detected, implying the presence of stronger acid sites. The authors proposed that these new peaks could be due to the formation of new bimetallic Mo-Ni compounds. TGA of the spent catalysts showed that the amount of carbon deposited on the catalysts increased with Ni loading and that the peak produced from burning of the carbon deposits shifted to higher temperatures as Ni content increased from 0.1 to 0.5 wt%. Similar effects had been noted when studying Fe-promoted Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts [65,68,70]. Additionally, a weak shoulder at higher temperature appeared in the DTA profiles, which became bigger as Ni content increased and was assigned to a new type of coke formed in the presence of Ni. Unlike Xu at al. [68,70] they did not associate this higher temperature peak to carbon nanotubes despite observing their presence in the spent catalysts by high resolution TEM (HR-TEM). Most revealing was the HR-TEM imaging of the catalyst with 0.1 wt% Ni and 4 wt% Mo after reaction. Various types and compositions of particles were found at different locations. Mo2C carbide particles within a size range of 5−30 nm were detected on the external surface of the zeolite, and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis demonstrated that their composition was slightly modified with Ni. These particles appeared covered by a graphite-like thin layer, therefore these Mo carbide clusters were probably inaccessible to methane and inactive. They also detected small Mo carbide clusters in the zeolite channels but did not detect any Ni content in them via EDX. No mention of carbon content inside the channels, other than carbidic carbon associated with the Mo2C clusters, was made. Carbon filaments were also observed by TEM, and while the morphology of these filaments did not change with varying Ni content, their amount and size did increase at higher Ni loading, reaching up to 100 nm in diameter in the catalyst with 2 wt% Ni. This could explain the increase in area and intensity of the high temperature peak in the DTA profiles as Ni content rose. Metal particles were detected at the ends of the carbon filaments and small metal inclusions were also detected inside the tubular filaments. EDX analysis showed that the metals at the ends of the filaments consisted of Mo-Ni alloys with varying compositions depending on the size of the particles, with higher Mo content in the larger particles. The smaller metal inclusions inside the filaments were mostly Ni-based. The locations of these metals in the carbon filaments were explained based on the mechanism of carbon filament growth, where metastable carbides formed at the active site of the metal surface activate the hydrocarbon molecules and catalyze carbon growth. The carbide degradation results in separation of a metal and carbon atoms which diffuse in opposite directions, with the carbons migrating to the back of the metal particle forming a graphite-like phase. The authors claimed that the active sites responsible for formation of benzene were Mo carbide clusters that were located inside the zeolite channels and remained unmodified by Ni. Visual inspection of their TEM images indicates that the carbon filaments originated on the external surface of the zeolite, which is something that would be expected given that their diameters were larger than the zeolite channels. Thus, it appears that the presence of Ni does not affect the aromatization active sites that are inside the channels, but rather the Ni species are involved in the formation of Mo-Ni alloys, on the external surface of the zeolite, that catalyze the formation of carbon nanotubes versus coke produced from polycondensation. These results are very similar to those obtained with Mo-Fe systems studied in MDA and while such detailed imaging analysis of the Mo-Fe/H-ZSM-5 catalysts has not been reported, it is very probable that similar structures are present in these systems as well. The authors argued that the presence of Ni led to a decreased rate of formation of coke because of their hydrogenating capacity, a speculation that agrees with the kinetic results obtained by Burns et al. [77]. Tang et al. [80] studied the effect of Co additive on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts with 3 wt% Mo and 1 wt% Co (Si/Al = 20). They found that the presence of Co improved the methane conversion and explained this to be due to Co promoting accelerated methane dehydrogenation. Acidifying the catalyst by soaking it in a HCl solution for 24 h further enhanced the catalytic activity but did not change the selectivity towards benzene. While the stability of the unmodified catalyst was not reported (all the activity data were presented only after one hour of reaction), the evolution of the activity over time of the optimum catalyst consisting of acidified and Co-modified Mo/ZSM-5 was presented over 2 h of reaction and showed that the catalyst was relatively stable. It should be noted however that two hours is a very short time period to draw conclusions regarding catalyst stability. Structural characterization of the catalyst presented in the study was sparse. Only X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed, analyzing the external surface of the catalyst. No Co was detected, and the only conclusion drawn from XPS measurements was that indeed the Mo species detected after reaction were in the form of Mo2C. In a separate study Xu et al. [81] did not observe promotional effects with the addition of 0.5 wt% Co to 5 wt% Mo/HZSM-5, which could be due to using an inadequate metal loading. Fila et al. [82] studied the effect of Co additive on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts with 4 wt% Mo and 0.4–1.6 wt% Co (Si/Al = 15). The N2 adsorption experiments showed metal addition did decrease the surface area and micropore volumes compared to the zeolite alone, but no specific trends were observed with different Co content and all differences in value seemed to fall within the range of the experimental error. No other structural characterization of the fresh catalysts was reported. Analysis of the activity showed that, as in the case of the other iron family metals, there was an optimum Co loading of 0.8 wt% that resulted in the highest rate of formation of benzene. The DTA of the spent catalysts showed one peak around 490 °C for the unmodified Mo catalyst, and the peak became broader and shifted to higher temperature with increasing Co content, similar to what had been observed by other groups studying Fe [65,68,70] and Ni [79] as additives. This result aligns with the elemental analysis of the catalysts post-reaction obtained by Burns et al. [77] who showed that the carbon/hydrogen ratio in the spent Mo-Co catalyst was higher than that obtained with the unmodified Mo catalyst. Upon increasing the reaction pressure from 150 kPa to 600 kPa, the stability of the Mo-Co catalyst improved, and the catalyst remained active for a longer period of time (from 25 to 35 h). In line with their previous work, Sridhar and coworkers [83] found that the effect of both Co and Ni dopants was enhanced when the catalysts were pretreated via temperature programmed reduction and carburization. They found that with 6 wt% Mo and Co or Ni loadings ranging from 0.2−1 wt%, no catalytic improvement was observed if catalysts were preheated in He. But, when they were pre-reduced, optimum loadings of Co (0.6 wt%) and Ni (0.2 wt%) resulted in both enhanced benzene yield and improved catalyst stability. In fact, the benzene yields hardly dropped in ten hours of reaction. Furthermore, when the pre-reduced doped catalysts were submitted to various hydrogen regeneration cycles, they demonstrated high stability (Fig. 7 ), whereas the monometallic Mo catalysts eventually lost stability after each cycle, suggesting that Mo-Co and Mo-Ni interactions could play a role in maintaining Mo stability over various reaction-regeneration cycles. 3.2 Metals with higher capacity to hydrogenate carbon deposits and increase stability (Pt, Rh, Pd, Ir, Ru, Cu, W) The metal additives discussed in this section present the capacity to hydrogenate carbon deposits and thus can lead to higher catalyst resistance to deactivation caused by coking. Moreover, they have the capability of promoting methane decomposition. Table 3 summarizes the catalytic data for the noble metal modified catalysts discussed in this section. Table 4 presents the structural and physicochemical properties reported by the most promising catalyst compositions from this section. Based on the capacity of noble metals to activate hydrogen and lead to hydrogenation of carbon deposits, Kojima et al. [84] explored the effect of Pt and Rh additives on Mo/ZSM-5 and Mo/MCM-22 catalysts, using 6 wt% Mo and adding Pt or Rh with Mo:X (X = noble metal) atomic ratio of 1:0.2. All reactions were run with a H2 co-feed (6–9 % of the feed). This H2 co-feed had shown enhanced catalyst stability with Mo alone, albeit with a drop in benzene rate of formation at the beginning of reaction compared to the unmodified catalyst. Adding the noble metals enhanced both the benzene selectivity and the catalyst stability further. Benzene selectivity rose from 70 % on the unmodified catalyst to 80 % on the noble metal-modified catalysts. The initial rate of formation of benzene was not affected much by the addition of the noble metals at the beginning of the reaction due to slight drop in methane conversion within the first hours of reaction, however, over time (+30 h), both Pt and Rh modified catalysts maintained their activity while the unmodified catalyst deactivated. The selectivity to naphthalene also dropped, which the authors attributed to hydrogenolysis of the heavy aromatics catalyzed by the noble metals in presence of the hydrogen co-feed. These enhancing effects of the noble metals were not observed in absence of H2 co-feed. TPO of the used catalysts demonstrated that indeed the quantity, nature, and distribution of the carbon deposits changed with the addition of the noble metals. There was an overall reduction in the formation of carbon deposits. Moreover, the higher temperature peak that has been assigned to heavier carbonaceous deposits held responsible for catalyst deactivation practically disappeared with the promoted catalysts, and more so with Pt than with Rh. These results pointed to the removal of carbon deposits by hydrogenation catalyzed by the noble metals in presence of hydrogen. Analyzing the XRD patterns of the catalysts, the authors detected very weak peaks that could be assigned to the metastable α-MoC1-x in the case of the carburized Pt and Rh-promoted Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. The unmodified carburized Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst only presented the β-Mo2C phase. Bouchy et al. [85] had observed in the past that the metastable Mo carbide species, α-MoC1-x, present higher stability in MDA reaction compared to β-Mo2C species. As a result of the detection of this metastable Mo carbide phase, the authors inferred that the noble metals modified the Mo oxide carburization pathway: the noble metals were reduced to their metallic state before the MoO3 species reduced to MoO2, and thus, led to the transformation of MoO3 to MoOxHyCz with an FCC structure via methane activation. This intermediate MoOxHyCz phase would then serve as a precursor to the α-MoC1-x phase upon further reduction. Based on the findings in this paper the authors concluded that the presence of noble metals improved catalyst stability via three different mechanisms: (1) by removing carbon deposits by catalyzing their hydrogenation, (2) increasing the selectivity to benzene instead of naphthalene, due to their capacity to catalyze hydrogenolysis of larger aromatic molecules, (3) by promoting the formation of the more stable α-MoC1-x phase upon carburization. Some years later, Tshabalala et al. [86] performed a study on the effect of Pt and Sn addition to Mo/ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 35) catalysts using 2 wt% Mo loadings combined with 0.5 wt% Pt and varying Sn loadings ranging from 0.05 wt% to 0.2 wt%. Contrary to Kojima et al. [84], they did not use H2 co-feed, and found that addition of Pt to Mo increased methane conversion and selectivity to aromatics. (The fact that Kojima et al. [84] had not perceived catalytic improvement with addition of Pt in the absence of H2 co-feed could be due to the much higher Mo loading they used in their study.) Addition of Sn decreased the methane conversion but was still higher than in the unpromoted Mo/ZMS-5 catalyst. The selectivity to aromatics on the other hand improved when Sn was added at low loadings, 0.05 and 0.1 wt% Sn, but at 0.2 wt% Sn, the selectivity dropped below that obtained with the Pt-Mo catalyst. Once again, as has been observed with other types of metallic additives in Mo-based MDA catalysts, optimal Sn loadings were required to achieve optimal catalytic performance. The selectivity to naphthalene dropped with Sn loading, while benzene selectivity increased. The authors attributed this preferred selectivity to benzene due to the presence of Pt and its capacity to catalyze hydrogenolysis of large aromatic molecules. It would seem however, that Sn would be in some way involved in the changes as well since changes in naphthalene selectivity were perceived when Pt loading was fixed and Sn loading was varied. Characterization of the fresh catalysts by XRD only showed diffraction peaks corresponding to the ZSM-5 support, indicating a high dispersion of the metal species as well as preservation of the crystallinity of the zeolite upon addition of metals. The BET surface areas and pore volumes of the Mo catalyst did not vary upon addition of Pt and Sn, suggesting that the metal additives were not occupying the zeolite channels, and instead were located on the external surface of the zeolite. NH3-TPD profiles showed that addition of Pt to the Mo/H-ZSM-5 decreased the concentration of BAS. But when small amounts of Sn were added, the drop in number of BAS happened to a higher extent, pointing to a stronger interaction of the Sn with the BAS of the zeolite. This strong interaction of Sn with acid sites has been observed when Sn is added to Al2O3 supported catalysts [87]. The additional drop in acidity with Sn loading correlated with the lower selectivity to aromatics as Sn loading increased, suggesting that Sn was interacting with BAS and thus reducing the amount of residual BAS responsible for condensation of the hydrocarbon products. The fact that Sn interacted with the BAS could also be indicative that it was entering the zeolite channels, where it could interact and modify the Mo sites, but no structural characterization results were shown to support this hypothesis. H2-TPR profiles showed that with addition of Pt the Mo reduction peaks were shifted to lower temperature, which could be explained due to the H2 spillover effect caused by dissociation of H2 on the Pt surface. On the other hand, once Sn was added, the second reduction peak of Mo (MoO2 to Mo0) shifted to higher temperature. The authors explained this shift to be a result of an interaction of Sn with Pt that would hamper the hydrogen spillover effect. This effect could be caused by an electronic effect or simply by covering of Pt by Sn, blocking access of the H2 molecules to the Pt sites. The stability of the modified catalysts seemed to improve only slightly. The TGA of the spent catalysts indicated a 16 % reduction in the amount of carbon deposits formed in reaction, which could explain the higher stability. The shift to lower temperature of the DTA peaks in presence of the Pt and Sn was attributed to the ability of Pt to catalyze the oxidation of the carbon deposits. Similar conclusions with respect to carbon formation had been drawn previously by Chen et al. [88] when studying 2 wt% Mo with 0.5−1 wt% Pt on HZSM-5. When Aboul-Gheit et al. [89] studied the use of other noble metal promoters with hydrogenating capacity, such as Pd and Ir (0.5 wt% Pd or Ir, with 6 wt% Mo), they found that indeed the amount of coke deposited after reaction was lower in presence of these additives. However, no improvement in formation of aromatics was observed, instead there was a rise in the selectivity to C2 species. They explained that the lower selectivity to aromatics was caused by a drop in the number of acid sites. On the other hand, Sily et al. [90] observed an enhancement in benzene selectivity and rate of formation when they modified a 2 wt% Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst with 0.3 wt% Ru. Modification with 0.3 wt% Pd improved benzene selectivity, but methane conversion dropped, resulting in lower benzene yield compared to the unmodified catalyst. No structural characterization of the fresh catalysts was provided, and H2-TPR results showed that while the additives were modifying the reducibility of the Mo oxides, these changes did not correlate with the catalytic performance. TPO analysis of the spent catalysts showed a lower amount of formation of “hard” coke with the Ru modified catalyst. Most of the groups employed the impregnation method to incorporate both Mo and the noble metal onto the zeolite structure. Hassan et al. [91] explored the promotional effect of Ru on Mo/ZSM-5 by incorporating the Ru first via an ion exchange method, followed by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of Mo using Mo(CO)6 precursor. The intent in using these methods was to obtain a higher dispersion of the metals compared to what is obtained by impregnation of metal precursors. In this way they prepared catalysts with 0.15 wt% Ru and Mo loadings varying between 1 and 3 wt%. The structural characterization of the catalysts provided in the paper was minimal, showing only textural analysis of the fresh catalysts by N2 adsorption. From the latter they found that although the metals were occupying the zeolite channels, they were not blocking them. Based on the activity results, the authors concluded that the optimum catalyst composition was 2 wt% Mo-0.15 wt% Ru, resulting in a benzene yield of 4.2 %, which is higher than the yield obtained with a 2 wt% Mo-0.3 wt% Ru catalysts prepared by the impregnation method by Sily et al. [90]. While Sily et al. [90] had not found a correlation between the reducibility of the Mo species and their catalytic performance, Shu et al. [92] attributed the improved activity and selectivity to aromatics found in their Ru promoted Mo catalysts to an observed enhancement in the reducibility of the Mo oxide species found via TPR. In their study they used a 2 wt% Mo/ZSM-5 with Mo/Ru ratios of 3–7. They also attributed the enhanced catalytic properties to a decrease in the concentration of strong acid sites and formation of new weak and medium strength ones deduced from NH3-TPD profiles. Temperature programmed reduction experiments and DTA experiments showed that the well dispersed Ru promoted the reduction of the initially formed Mo oxide species which promotes the activation of methane. In their work with 0.5 wt% Ru-5 wt% Mo/ZSM-5, Xu et al. [68] had found a drop in the intensity of the NH3 –desorption peak in the NH3-TPD profiles, assigned to strong acid sites, when Ru was present. They interpreted this as a promotional effect of Ru that was improving the interaction of Mo with the BAS inside the zeolite channels. They later confirmed by testing a 0.5 wt% Ru/ZSM-5 that this reduced peak intensity was due to the decomposition of NH3 into N2 and H2 over the Ru during NH3 adsorption. Hence the addition of Ru was not modifying the strong acid sites and the change in intensity of the NH3 desorption peak could not be interpreted as an increase in the interaction of Mo with the BAS. Li et al. [93] studied the effect of Cu addition on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. Cu was incorporated by ion exchange into ZSM-5 and the Cu/HZSM-5 was then physically mixed with MoO3 and calcined in order to allow Mo oxide species to migrate into the zeolite channels. The catalysts contained 3 wt% Mo, but the Cu content was not disclosed in the article. The Cu/HZSM-5 catalyst showed some activity in MDA, but Mo/HZSM-5 performance was much better. The Mo-Cu/HZSM-5 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance, with both higher methane conversion and higher benzene selectivity. This Cu-doped catalyst was also more stable than the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. To delve more into the causes of the Cu promotion, the catalysts were structurally characterized by XPS. It is important to note that XPS data interpretation depends on the conditions in which the measurements are taken. Mo carbide species are formed in reaction, but the outer layer of these carbides oxidizes easily when they are exposed to air, thus interpretation of Mo oxidation states can be erroneous if the XPS measurements are not performed in situ. The authors in this paper did not specify in situ measurement conditions for the acquisition of the XPS data, therefore we assume that the catalysts were taken out of the reactors and exposed to air before the XPS measurements. The XPS measurements of the fresh catalysts show that in the unmodified Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst both Mo6+ and Mo5+ species existed in the catalyst, while the Cu-modified catalyst presented mostly Mo6+ species. After reaction (and considering that the samples were exposed to air and thus are not representative of the state in reaction) the unmodified catalysts presented Mo4+ species while the Cu-modified catalyst presented mostly Mo5+ species. While some of the oxidized species may have formed after exposure to air, it is clear that the presence of Cu inhibited the reduction of the Mo species. Meanwhile, in both catalysts the Cu existed in the Cu2+ state in the fresh catalysts and was reduced to Cu0 after reaction. The authors did not observe carbides via XPS and therefore discarded Mo carbides as active species and instead proposed Mo5+ species as responsible for methane activation. We believe that such an assumption based on only XPS characterization which is performed ex situ is misleading and defies results found by a multitude of other researchers. It is however interesting to keep in mind that the XPS results pose some insight onto the effect that Cu could have on the reducibility of Mo. Based on the idea that Mo carbides are responsible for aromatization, and the fact that Cu seems to suppress Mo reduction, it seems counterintuitive that the catalytic activity and benzene selectivity both improved in presence of Cu. Contrasting these results with TPR profiles of these catalysts would certainly provide more insight into the effect of Cu on the reducibility of the Mo sites but this type of measurement was not performed in this work. In this same work the authors also demonstrated with 27Al Magic Angle Spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (27Al-MAS NMR) that the extraction of tetrahedrally coordinated Al from the zeolite framework to form octahedrally coordinated Al2(MoO4)3 was reduced in presence of Cu, which could account for the presence of a higher number of active Mo species leading to higher catalytic performance and stability. Analysis of the carbon deposits formed after reaction by TGA indicated that the presence of Cu inhibited the formation of “hard” coke deposits. Therefore, it seems that Cu improved catalytic performance by preventing formation of both Al2(MoO4)3 and “hard” coke. Qi et al. [69] also studied the effect of adding Cu to Mo/ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 25) catalysts employing Cu:Mo molar ratios of 0.03 to 0.05. Comparison of their results with previous works must be handled carefully as their synthesis method was markedly different. They explored the use of microwave heating to prepare the catalysts and observed that most of the metal species remained on the external surface of the zeolite, thus the catalysts were fundamentally different from the ones studied by Li et al. [93]. Despite this, they did observe improvements in methane conversion and benzene selectivity when the catalyst was modified with Cu (Fig. 8 (a) and (b)). They attributed the enhancement in catalytic behavior to a decline in carbon deposition in the presence of Cu as observed by TGA of the spent catalysts (Fig. 8 (c)). Xu et al. [81] on the other hand explored the effect of Cu addition to Mo/HZMS-5 and observed no catalytic enhancement. They only tested 0.5 wt% Cu on a 5 wt% Mo on HZSM-5 catalyst. Given the general trend that the optimum loading of most additives tends to be low, it is possible that the Cu loading they used was too high to lead to any type of promotion. While it was not the main goal of their paper, Wong et al. [94] presented some preliminary work on the promotional effect of W over Mo/HZSM-5 for MDA reactions. The activity and stability of the W-Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts were found to be improved, but the catalyst composition was not reported. The promotional effects of W on the catalytic activity and stability was suggested to be due to the formation of mixed Mo-W oxide, either bimetallic or closely interacted, however, no structural characterization of this catalyst reported, and these conclusions remain speculative. The authors suggested that the presence of W oxide in the Mo oxide matrix can lead to an ensemble effect, which may restrict the formation of graphite or sintering of molybdenum active species thereby avoiding the blocking of active sites by graphite. 3.3 Metals affecting acidity of the catalyst (Cr, Ag, Ga) Given the possible roles that BAS play in the reaction pathways proposed for MDA (see section 2), much effort has been placed in studying the effect that the acidity of the metal/zeolite catalysts plays in their activity in MDA. A large body of literature is dedicated to modifying the acidity of the zeolite support before and after impregnation of Mo, and there are several extensive reviews that cover this topic [29,32,35,38]. Based on the scope of our review, here we will only focus on research carried out on Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts where modification in catalyst acidity is merely conferred by the presence of the second metal. Table 5 summarizes the catalytic data for Mo catalysts modified with Cr, Ag, and Ga. Table 6 presents the structural and physicochemical properties reported by the most promising catalyst compositions from this section. Zhang et al. [95] observed with 3.5 wt% Mo on ZSM-5 that when small amounts of Cr (Cr/Mo molar ratio of 0.07) were employed as additive, catalyst acidity increased and resulted in improved methane conversion and benzene selectivity. Most of the focus in this paper was placed on characterization of the acidity of the catalysts via NH3-TPD and isopropyl alcohol decomposition (via TPSR) as a more precise method to quantify the number of BAS. Clearly the presence of Cr increased the number of strong acid sites. The enhancement in methane conversion and benzene selectivity was explained based on the model of hydrocarbon formation established by Xu et al.
