[24,96] involving acid-assisted heterolytic splitting of methane according to the following scheme: (1) C H 4 → M o O x C H 3 + − H − (2) C H 3 + − H − → M o O x , H + C H 3 + + H 2 (3) C H 3 + → M o O x C H 2 + H z + No other structural characterization was performed, thus definitive conclusions on the structure-activity relationship cannot be made. Ngobeni et al. [97] explored the effect of using both B and Ag as additives to Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. The motivation was based on other catalytic systems that showed that B could increase the dispersion of Mo on alumina supports as well as modifying their acidity [98,99]. Meanwhile Ag/ZSM-5 is known to be active in non-oxidative conversion of methane to both higher hydrocarbons (when ethylene is co-fed) [100,101] and to C2 products [102]. Thus, they hypothesized that addition of B could affect the dispersion of Mo, and Ag could further enhance the activation of methane. Catalysts with 2 wt% Mo were modified by 0−0.2 wt% B and 0.5 wt% Ag. For Mo-B catalysts it was found that the presence of 0.2 wt% B enhanced the selectivity to C2 generally, and to ethylene particularly. When 0.05 wt% B was added, the selectivity to aromatics also improved a bit, but decreased with higher B content. TPR results showed that the reducibility of the MoO3 species was enhanced in the presence of B, which they speculated could be due to the effect of the presence of B prior to the impregnation of the Mo precursor, that affected the dispersion of the Mo species inside the channels, or due to the direct interaction of B with Mo. Analysis of the NH3-TPD showed that the intensity of the peak corresponding to strong acid sites did not vary with addition of B. No changes in the coordination sphere of Mo were detected with UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (DRS). When Ag, in the form of Ag2+ ions, was used as an additive with Mo, both methane conversion and benzene selectivity improved. While the Ag/ZSM-5 catalyst was capable of activating methane, the methane conversions were lower than for Mo/ZSM-5 and the catalyst presented no selectivity to aromatics, thus a synergy was established when both Mo and Ag were present. As in the case of B, the UV–vis DRS spectra indicated that the coordination sphere of Mo remained unchanged and was tetrahedral in the presence of Ag ions. Py-FTIR suggested a growth in the number of BAS when Ag was added. Similar to the case of Cr, it is possible that the higher acidity created by the Ag enhanced the heterolytic splitting of methane leading to enhanced conversion and aromatics production. Liu et al. [103] evaluated the effect of Ga dopant on Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts with 3 wt% Mo and 0.1−1 wt% Ga (Si/Al = 30). The Ga and Mo precursors were co-impregnated. TPR of the catalysts showed that the presence of Ga resulted in a shift of the first reduction peak (MoO3 → MoO2) to a lower temperature, thus facilitating the reducibility of the Mo oxides on the zeolite. Furthermore, this happened to a larger extent as Ga content increased from 0.1 to 1 wt%. This change in reducibility seemed to affect the catalyst activity and selectivity, with benzene selectivity increasing and coke selectivity decreasing as Ga loading increased. Based on the hypothesis that the amount of coke deposits formed increases with a higher number of BAS, they speculated that the Ga species were replacing protons at the zeolite BAS and thus decreasing the number of residual BAS. The optimum catalytic performance was observed with the catalyst with the lowest Ga loading which was 0.1 wt%. Analysis of the carbon deposited on the catalyst with the highest Ga loading of 1 wt% was performed by TPO and showed that as the reaction time increased, the nature of the coke deposits became heavier. After the first 7 h of reaction, coke deposits that burnt off at around 500 °C were formed, which were assigned to polyethylene and heavier aromatics. As time on stream increased, the lower temperature peak became much less intense and instead a broad peak in the 550−700 °C range appeared, which they assigned to amorphous and graphitic carbon formed by cracking and dehydrogenation of the hydrocarbon deposits. While the structures of these carbons were not characterized, these conclusions were probably drawn from previous literature references. What is clear is that the longer the catalysts remained in reaction, the more difficult it was to remove the coke deposits. No data on characterization of the spent unmodified Mo catalyst was provided, thus it is not clear whether the presence of Ga was affecting the nature or quantity of carbon deposits compared to those formed on an unmodified Mo catalyst. Several years later, the same research group [104] analyzed in more detail the structure of the working catalysts by quenching them in N2 at different times of reaction and characterizing them by XPS, X-ray Auger emission spectroscopy (XAES), TPO-TG, and HR-TEM. Analysis of the TEM images of the catalyst after four hours of reaction showed very similar metal structures to those observed by Vosmerikov et al. [79] with Mo-Ni catalysts. Mo2C particles with 3−5 nm in size were observed on the external surface of the zeolite, and were covered in a graphitic type layer, indicating that they were probably only active at the beginning of the reaction and deactivated once they were covered completely by the carbon layer. The external surface of the zeolite was covered in what seemed like a layer of amorphous carbon. Interestingly, the Mo clusters detected inside the zeolite channels showed a low content in carbon, which would suggest that carbon was not formed inside the channels. This finding coincides with the results of Vosmerikov et al. [79] and points to the major cause of deactivation being blocking of channel openings on the external surface of the zeolite. Fig. 9 shows the TEM images they used to arrive to these conclusions. The XAES spectra pointed to a change in the degree of hydrogenation of the carbon species with time. The first carbon deposits contained more hydrogen but with time they were more dehydrogenated and formed more aromatic type carbon, both amorphous and graphitic, which agreed with what was observed in the TEM images. To understand that difference in activity of the Ga-promoted and the unmodified Mo catalysts, XPS and XAES of both catalysts were compared. XPS showed that there was COx adsorption on the surface of the Ga-promoted catalyst, while XAES indicated that there was favorable alkene formation on the surface of the Ga-promoted catalyst, explaining the higher yields to C2 and aromatic species with addition of Ga. The higher capacity of COx adsorption by Ga was related to the capacity of this catalyst to burn carbon deposits at 700 °C, thus helping improve yields to C2 and aromatics and catalyst stability. The effect of Ga on the acidity of the catalysts was different from that of Cr and Ag, since here the change in acidity was caused by occupation of the BAS, whereas Cr and Ag seemed to infer higher acidity to the catalyst by their nature and without affecting the BAS of the zeolite support. A plot of the selectivity-conversion data points pertaining to the most promising Mo-X catalyst compositions representing each of the X elements discussed in this section is represented in Fig. 10 . The data points correspond to the ones that appear in Tables 1, 3, and 5 and the catalyst compositions that are represented were selected based on the those that provided the highest yields to benzene within each study. No particular trends are observed, due to the different metal loadings and synthesis methods employed in each study, however, the figure provides a sense of the relative performance of the catalysts in the different studies. Only one system seems to be superior to all the rest, that is the Mo-Cu system studied in reference [69]. Different from all the other studies, the catalysts here were prepared by microwave heating, and most of the metals were claimed to reside on the external surface of the zeolite. The fact that with this location the catalytic performance would be superior to that obtained when Mo resides inside the zeolite channels is surprising. Also, in this study, a methane conversion of 19 % was measured, which is much higher than thermodynamic equilibrium value for MDA, thus, it is possible that other parallel reactions were taking place in this system. Further work would be required to explain this unusual result. 4 Emerging trends with other non-Mo based multifunctional methane dehydroaromatization catalysts As mentioned in the first section of this review, zeolites modified with metals other than Mo have been tested in MDA, and while they have shown capacity to activate methane and lead to formation of aromatics, their catalytic performances are still inferior to the Mo-based catalysts. Recently however there have been some emerging trends in modifying these non-Mo based catalysts in order to improve their performance by adding other metal promoters. We refer to these as non-Mo based multifunctional MDA catalysts and describe them in more detail below. Table 7 summarizes the catalytic data for the catalysts discussed in this section. 4.1 Fe-based catalysts Fe has been used as a promoter for Mo/ZSM-5 based catalysts as discussed in the previous sections. Monometallic Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts have also been explored as alternative MDA catalysts [19–21,105] and it is thought that Fe carbides formed in the reaction induction period are responsible for the MDA activity. However, deactivation by coking remains an issue and benzene selectivity and yield are lower than those obtained with Mo-based catalysts. Recently various groups have been exploring the strategy of improving the catalytic performance of Fe-modified zeolite catalysts by using different metal dopants. Denardin and Perez-Lopez prepared Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts with 5 wt% Fe loading and studied the effect of modifying them with 1 wt% of different additives. In one study [106] they explored the effect of two types of metals: transition metals and alkali metals separately. They used transition metals, Cu, Ni, Co and Zn with the intention of modifying the reducibility of the Fe species and exploring how this would affect the induction period for formation of Fe carbides and consequent catalytic activity. Alkali metals, Ca, Mg, and La were employed to modify the acidity of the zeolite and explore the effect on catalytic performance. Through H2-TPR and NH3-TPD experiments, they found that both types of additives affected both the acidity of the catalysts and the reducibility of the Fe oxides, thus it was not possible to study the two phenomena separately. The presence of none of the additives improved the rate of formation or selectivity to benzene compared to the unmodified Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst, however, the additives did modify the physicochemical properties of the samples which could potentially be beneficial for the catalyst performance if harnessed properly. In particular, they found that addition of Cu improved the reducibility of the FeO species to Fe0, which translated into a shorter induction period for the formation of Fe carbides leading to a fast approach to the maximum rate of formation of benzene compared to the unmodified catalyst. The presence of Cu also increased the strength of the acid sites in the catalysts, but the authors claimed that the effect of the additives on the reducibility has a stronger impact on the catalytic performance. In the case of the alkali metal additives, it was found that the Ca-modified catalyst showed the least formation of carbon deposits after reaction, compared to the other alkali metal modified catalysts, and this correlated with the fact that Ca led to an optimum decrease in the acidity of the catalysts. Mg decreased the acidity to a higher extent, but no aromatics were formed in its presence, which the authors attributed to neutralization of strong acid sites that would be essential for the aromatization reaction to take place. Ca decreased the acidity to a degree that could minimize coking while still allowing the presence of sufficient residual strong acid sites required for the reaction pathway towards aromatics. In their following work, Denardin and coworkers [107] studied the effect of the addition of the fifth period transition metals (1 wt% Zr, Mo, Nb) into 5 wt% Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst for MDA. The addition of these metals did not change the strength and type of acid sites of all the catalysts although the reducibility of Fe was significantly influenced. Based on the TPR profiles, the authors concluded that Mo and Nb showed a stronger interaction with the Fe species compared to Zr, and this correlated with the induction period in reaction, with the Zr-modified catalyst showing a shorter induction period compared to the unmodified Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst. This catalyst also maintained a relatively high benzene selectivity and benzene production rate, and the lowest selectivity to coke compared to the other catalysts. These researchers also analyzed the pore size distribution of the different catalysts and found that the pore sizes were not being modified in presence of the metals, suggesting that most of the metal interactions were probably taking place on the external surface of the zeolite. With the aim of increasing the dehydrogenation ability of the Fe-based catalysts, Sim et al. [108] explored the effect of noble metals as dopants. They observed that the introduction of 0.5 wt% of noble metals Au, Ag, Pt, and Rh into 2 wt% Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts not only increased the methane conversion and the benzene selectivity compared to Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst but also reduced the induction period. Among all the catalysts the Au-promoted Fe/ZSM-5 displayed the highest catalytic activity and stability for MDA. They found via XPS measurements that the presence of Au led to the highest Fe content on the external surface compared to the other noble metal modified catalysts, and they associated this to a higher dispersion of Fe on the zeolite surface. This was corroborated by STEM imaging with EDS mapping which showed smaller Fe aggregates formed in the presence of Au compared to the unmodified Fe catalyst. They maintained that the enhanced dispersion of Fe along with the smaller particle size of agglomerated Fe particles samples resulted in higher carburization degree of Fe species in the Fe-Au catalyst. XRD patterns of the spent catalysts indeed showed a sharper peak corresponding to Fe carbide in the Au modified catalyst compared to the other samples. The addition of Au atoms in Fe/ZSM-5 also caused a reduction in the amount of Brønsted acid sites which in turn provided an adequate amount of acidity, leading to reduced coke formation. It is interesting to note that, contrary to the findings of Denardin et al. [106,107], a direct correlation between the reducibility of Fe species and the catalytic activity was not observed. The introduction of Pt and Rh significantly promoted the reduction properties of Fe/ZSM-5, whereas, the addition of Au and Ag had little effect on the reducibility of Fe species. Nevertheless, the presence of Au seemed to enhance the formation of Fe carbide species and led to the highest promotional effect on the catalytic performance of Fe/ZSM-5. 4.2 Pt-based catalyst Based on the capacity of Pt sites to activate methane, Gerceker et al. [109] studied the nonoxidative conversion of methane over Sn promoted Pt catalysts using two types of supports: SiO2 and ZSM-5. The work was not specifically focused on forming aromatics, but rather on comparing the effect of the support on the catalytic ability of the Pt and Pt-Sn sites to activate methane and om the consequent reaction and product distribution. They found that ZSM-5 supported metals presented higher activity than the SiO2-supported catalysts due to the formation of larger metal nanoparticles in the latter. The location of the metal sites in the ZSM-5 supported catalysts was not analyzed although based on the BET surface area measurements they did infer that probably some of the metals were entering the zeolite channels. When testing zeolites with different Si/Al ratios, they observed, as would be expected, that increasing number of BAS led to an increase in the benzene formation rates, which they attributed to bifunctionality acquired by the catalyst. When contrasting the profiles of the ethylene and benzene formation rates over time on stream, they observed that they all showed volcano-shaped profiles which they claimed suggested that the reaction was happening via a “hydrocarbon pool” mechanism. In general, the benzene selectivity obtained with these catalysts only reached ∼ 10 %, in contrast to the 70–80 % benzene selectivity values obtained in the literature with Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts. However, the selectivities to ethylene were much higher than aromatics and when comparing the catalysts with similar loadings (0.58 wt%) of Pt-Sn and Mo on ZSM-5, they found that the rate of formation of carbon products (counted as the sum of ethylene, benzene, and naphthalene) was similar. Their DFT calculations and microkinetic modelling predicted that Pt3Sn step sites were probably cleaner than Pt sites, leading to higher ethylene TOF values. This was in agreement with the experimental results, and further supports the fact that a close interaction between the two metals can lead to modifications in the active sites that lead to higher catalytic activity. 5 Process intensification of methane dehydroaromatization Changing the catalyst composition by doping with metal promoters has been discussed in detail in the previous sections and while improvements in stability have been observed, catalyst design strategies cannot overcome the low single-pass conversions due to the thermodynamic constraints of MDA. Process intensification strategies based on engineering different reactor configurations can break the thermodynamic barrier, but generally lead to faster catalyst coking. Multifunctional catalysts engineered specifically to be resistant to coking are ideal candidates to employ in these intensified processes and present a potentially viable path towards establishing a process that can lead to deployment of MDA. We refer the reader to various review articles that discuss in detail the various process intensification strategies that have been investigated for MDA in the past few decades, including the use of hydrogen selective membrane reactors that remove H2 product and shift the reaction equilibrium to formation of more products [110–117]; addition of oxidant co-reactants that reduce catalyst coking [27,52,60,71,118–121]; use of co-reactants such as C2Hx or acetic acid [122,123]; use of fluidized reactors that facilitate continuous catalyst regeneration [124–127]. Here we will comment on several of the most recent processes that have not been covered in detail in previous reviews. 5.1 Absorptive H2 scavenging Recent studies by Bhan and coworkers [128] employed in situ absorptive H2 removal as a strategy to overcome thermodynamic limitations that limit the CH4 conversion in MDA to ∼10 %. They employed Zr as an absorbent to pre-carburized Mo/H-ZSM-5 in a polyfunctional formulation, an interpellet physical mixture of 2:1 wt ratio (Zr metal:MoCx/H-ZSM-5) and observed 27 % maximum single-pass CH4 conversion and an enhanced yield of hydrocarbon products. This was attributed to the circumvention of equilibrium limitations by the hydrogen absorptive function of Zr, while maintaining a high selectivity to aromatics. This is a significantly higher conversion compared to the equilibrium conversion (∼10 %) in similar reaction conditions. The catalyst was later regenerated by thermal treatment in helium flow, enabling the use of the catalyst in successive reaction-regeneration cycles with significant above-equilibrium CH4 conversions. The MDA products observed at the reaction outlet remained unchanged suggesting that the reaction pathways for MDA were not modified by addition of Zr absorbent. The authors claimed that the cumulative aromatic product selectivity of the MDA, calculated as the ratio of aromatic products formed (mol C), to the total products observed (mol C), is retained upon the addition of Zr, which leads to the enhancement of aromatic yields and CH4 turnovers. They reported an increase in product yields by a factor of 1.4–5.4 using the catalyst with Zr, as compared to the unmodified Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. The authors also reported H2 tracer kinetic studies in a subsequent publication [129] which emphasizes the significance of dispersive H2 transport during the MDA process. An optimal dispersive/diffusive H2 transport to Zr for absorption, coupled with the catalytic function of the MoCx sites is required to enhance net aromatization rates. 5.2 Coupling with chemical looping A recent study by Brady and coworkers [130] shows that the thermodynamic limitation of MDA can be circumvented by the method of coupling MDA with chemical looping to achieve reactive separation of H2 from the aromatic products of MDA reaction. The authors demonstrated the effectiveness of chemical looping as a reactive separation technology to remove H2 produced in MDA and increase the equilibrium methane conversion and aromatic products yield. Fig. 11 (a) shows the combined dehydroaromatization and chemical looping cycle. The strategy comprises of a four-step cycle consisting of (i) MDA on Mo/HZSM-5, (ii) removal of H2, (iii) regeneration of H2 on a Fe3O4/FeO redox catalyst, and (iv) H2O removal on zeolite 5A. In the first step methane is flown over the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, where the MDA reaction at 973 K produces an equilibrated mixture of methane, aromatics and H2. The second step involves H2 being selectively oxidized to water, by flowing through Fe3O4, thereby reducing the metal oxide. H2 is then regenerated by reoxidation of the reduced oxide using water in the third step. Steps 2 and 3 combine to separate the H2 from the effluent in step 1. The final step consists of the removal of H2O produced in step 2 using a high temperature water adsorbent which can then be regenerated by desorbing the water by means of a temperature swing. The methane and aromatics recovered from the MDA effluent in step 1 is used as a feed for the subsequent cycle in MDA. The absence of H2 in the feed restores the thermodynamic driving force of the MDA. By repeating these four steps multiple times, the authors were able to reach aromatic yields up to > 40 %. The authors also show that equilibrium conversion of methane increases with the number of stages of the cycle. Fig. 11 (b) and (c) shows the thermodynamic equilibrium conversion of methane with stages of hydrogen removal between aromatization stages at 100 % H2 removal at different temperatures, and that at 700 °C at different degrees of H2 removal respectively. The equilibrium conversion of methane and 100 % selectivity to benzene was assumed. The number of stages required to reach the methane conversion decreased with increase in temperature. Meanwhile, the number of stages required to reach the methane conversion increased with the decrease in degree of hydrogen removal. 5.3 Coupling with methylation reaction Methanol can readily react with aromatic compounds such as benzene and toluene on acidic zeolite catalysts to form ring or side chain methylation products. Xu and coworkers [131] have reported an effective method to enhance MDA activity and stability by coupling MDA with methylation of the product benzene in sequence over Mo/HZS-5 catalyst realized by co-feeding small amounts of CH3OH with CH4. This led to an improved methane conversion and product stability at extended time-on-stream. The mechanism involves two steps viz., (i) formation of benzene via MDA, and (ii) benzene methylation with methanol. The coupling of these two reactions yielded the desired products benzene, toluene and xylene with a selectivity of >90 % and a CH4 conversion of >25 % with an excellent catalytic stability. During the MDA reaction the CH4 is converted to C2 species by MoCx which cyclizes to form aromatics inside the zeolite channels. The methanol which is strongly adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites as surface methoxy species reacts with the benzene molecule in the vicinity to form toluene and xylene, by the cleavage of CO bond on the acidic zeolite. The selective removal of benzene shifts the equilibrium of the MDA reactions towards the products. Moreover, by coupling these two reactions, the reaction rates of both the MDA and methylation would be improved since the former is endothermic and the latter an exothermic reaction. 6 Summary and outlook The drastic rise in shale gas production and the consequent drop in prices of natural gas in the past decades has encouraged the quest for alternative uses of methane as a chemical feedstock in the manufacturing industry. While two-step syngas routes for valorization of methane are currently deployed commercially, there is an increasing interest in developing direct processing routes for conversion of methane to upgraded chemicals. Not only can direct methane upgrade reduce processing costs, it can also reduce the effects of methane leaks and flaring. Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a one-step reaction capable of upgrading methane to hydrogen and benzene and can potentially be used to close the current gap between the demand and production of aromatics. Mo/H-ZSM-5 and Mo/MCM-22 are by far the most efficient catalysts in MDA at present. The technological challenges with the MDA rest on its thermodynamic limitations (it is highly endothermic and possesses low one-pass methane conversion) and on fast catalyst deactivation due to coking. Process intensification solutions are capable of successfully increasing the one-pass conversion, leading to higher benzene yields. But they also inevitably lead to even faster catalyst coking. Knowledge of the catalyst structure-activity relationship and the role that the catalyst structure plays in the deactivation pathways can allow for development of rational catalyst design strategies to improve catalyst performance and mitigate deactivation. Within this context, here we have reviewed a strategy that has been employed extensively to improve catalyst stability by incorporating a second metal, X, to the Mo/ZSM-5 system, that is capable of modulating the deactivation pathway and conferring multifunctionality to the catalytic system. Based on the modus operandi of the second metal in mitigating catalyst deactivation, in this review we have classified Mo-X multifunctional catalysts studied so far into three groups: (1) transition metals that lead to formation of carbon deposits in the form of carbon nanotubes (Fe, Co, Ni); (2) noble metals with capacity to hydrogenate carbon deposits in situ (Pt, Rh, Pd, Ir, Ru, Cu); (3) metals that modify catalyst acidity (Cr, Ag, Ga). While these additives seem to improve catalyst performance and stability, analysis of the work published in the literature indicates that various fundamental questions remain unanswered, especially those related to the structure-activity relationships. Particular challenges are: (1) the identification of the nature of the Mo-X interactions; (2) determination of the relative locations of Mo and X within the zeolite structure; (3) effect of X on the evolution of the Mo species during the reaction induction period. These challenges are discussed in more detail next. A direct evidence of Mo-X interactions would be formation of Mo-X bimetallic moeities, however, their detection has remained understandably elusive: it is generally observed that the optimum loadings of the second metal are usually low and, in most cases, much lower than that of Mo itself. For this reason, it has proven to be almost impossible to directly detect formation of bimetallic species in any of these Mo-X catalysts. Only Masiero et al. [65] were capable of detecting very weak Fe2(MoO4)3 XRD peaks for their as-prepared Mo-Fe/H-ZSM-5 catalysts. This phase would have to be located on the external surface of the ZSM-5 support in order to be detected by XRD, since clusters that fit inside the channels would be smaller than the detection limit of XRD. The location of the metals, with respect to each other and in the zeolite structure, is an important factor to consider in these metal/zeolite systems when trying to elucidate the nature of Mo-X interactions. It is thought that the metal sites that are confined within the zeolite channels lead to production of benzene and other aromatics, due to the product shape selectivity conferred by the dimension of the zeolite pores. To prepare the Mo catalysts, the zeolite support is usually impregnated with a Mo precursor solution and then dried and calcined in air. During this calcination step the Mo precursors oxidize and break down into smaller clusters that are capable of migrating inside the zeolite channels and anchoring to the framework at the BAS. A question that has not been fully addressed in the literature of the Mo-X multifunctional catalysts is the determination of the location of the second metal, X. Knowledge of the relative location of both Mo and X would provide insight on whether their catalytic functions rely on a close proximity between them or whether they function separately. Reviewing the work carried out with most of the additives in Section 3 of this review suggests that these metals remain on the outer surface of the zeolite. This conclusion is drawn from analysis of the changes in micropore volume when the second metal, X, is added to the zeolite; changes in the number of residual BAS after adding the second metal; TEM-EDX imaging and XPS analysis. While these methods can give some insight into the possible migration of the second metal into the zeolite channels, they are not accurate enough given the extremely small amounts of second metal that are used in the Mo-X systems. In other words, if the second metal were to enter the zeolite channel, given its small population, it would probably not lead to significant changes in pore volume or number of BAS. Furthermore, it is important to keep in mind that most of these studies employed the NH3-TPD method to quantify the BAS. While this method can quantify the overall number of acid sites and inform on the relative strength of the different types of acid sites, it is not an accurate method for quantifying the number of BAS. Most authors drew conclusions regarding quantification of the BAS by assigning the higher temperature peaks appearing in the NH3-TPD profiles to BAS. Other more accurate techniques, such as Py-FTIR (employed in references [67] and [97], 1H-MAS-NMR, and isopropyl amine TPD (IPA-TPD) (employed in reference [95]) would need to be employed to draw more precise correlations between Mo-X catalyst compositions and the number of residual BAS present in the zeolite channels after metal incorporation. TEM-EDX measurements provided in some of the research with Ni [79] and Ga [103,104] additives seem to indicate that the clusters in the zeolite channels close to the zeolite surface are mostly constituted of Mo and carbon and show no content in the second metal. Both Vosmerikov et al. [79] (with Ni additive) and Sun et al. [67] (with Fe additive) suggested that the transition metal additives, Ni and Fe, remained on the external surface of the zeolite and that nano-sized Ni, Fe, and Ni-Mo or Fe-Mo alloy particles on the external surface induced polycondensation of the aromatic molecules at the channel mouths towards carbon nanotubes instead of towards coke deposits that could block the pores. The fact that the tubular and open structure of the carbon nanotubes allows for continued diffusion of both methane to the active sites and aromatic products away from the zeolite makes it a viable explanation as to how these additives enhance catalyst stability and mitigate coking effects. But whether possible Mo-X interactions inside the channels are also playing a role in the catalyst activity remains elusive, and yet, could be an important factor that could influence the structure-activity relationship. The importance of Mo-X interactions within the zeolite channels is underpinned by the results obtained for monometallic Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts: Beale and coworkers [54] demonstrated, by combining in situXAS measurements with high resolution XRD involving Rietveld refinement, that during reaction the Mo carbide species located inside the zeolite channels migrate to the external surface, at which point the catalyst loses product shape selectivity and deactivates due to preferred coking pathways caused by unselective reactions taking place at the Mo sites on the external zeolite surface. If this hypothesized deactivation pathway really occurs, then introducing additives capable of retaining the Mo inside the channels could also lead to less coking and deactivation. Sridhar et al. [83] observed via TGA of as-prepared Mo-Ni and Mo-Co catalysts that the presence of the second metal increased the temperature of volatilization of the Mo oxides, implying that Ni and Co could potentially reduce Mo mobility inside the channels, as long as they are in close proximity, and in this way also mitigate catalyst deactivation. Other groups have demonstrated that the presence of the second metal affects the reducibility of the Mo species [67,86,92,97,103], further confirming an interaction between the two metals. However, it is not possible to distinguish if this interaction is occurring on the external surface of the zeolite or within the channels. In the case of the group of noble metal additives with hydrogenating capacity, it was found that adding Pt, Rh, Ru, Pd, Ir, and Cu to Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts reduced the formation of “hard”, polyaromatic, hydrogen-poor carbon deposits which are thought to be responsible for catalyst deactivation. This decrease in coking was explained by the capacity of these noble metals of dissociating H2 (a product of the MDA reaction) which is capable of hydrogenating the carbon deposits. Furthermore, in the case of Pt additive, its capacity to catalyze hydrogenolysis of larger aromatic molecules prevents their subsequent condensation to coke. Instead, more benzene is formed as a result of this reaction pathway. It is important to mention that apart from playing a role as a hydrogenating agent, these metals can also catalyze methane decomposition to hydrogen and carbon, leading to methane conversions that are higher than the theoretical thermodynamic equilibrium conversion calculated for MDA. Once again, in these studies with noble metal additives, as well as in those treating additives thought to enhance heterolytic splitting of methane, Cr and Ag, little was mentioned regarding the location of the additives, and yet it is an important factor to determine in order to understand the exact mechanism by which these additives modify the reaction pathway and whether preferred locations are required in order to maximize the catalytic enhancement. The question on the relative location of Mo and X and the effect on catalytic performance, regardless of the actual functionality of X, makes it necessary to identify the location of both metals and seek for avenues to demonstrate the existence of an interaction between them. The problem is further complicated by the fact that even in monometallic Mo catalysts, multiple types of Mo sites can coexist, both inside the channels and on the external surface, and the exact nature of the active site has not been determined yet. One way of disentangling this problem is by employing synthesis methods that can enable preparation of model catalysts by allowing a precise control of the location of the metals both inside the channels and on the external surface of the zeolite. One possible avenue to achieve this is by previous silanation of the acid sites of the zeolite residing on its external surface. Iglesia’s research group [132] found that by silanation they were able to direct a larger number of Mo oxides inside the channels. Whether this procedure would have the same effect on a second metal remains an open question and requires further exploration. Another avenue for synthesis of metal/zeolite systems with controlled location of metals can be inferred from work on other single metal-zeolite catalysts for MDA, which has shown the synthesis method and the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite play important roles in the resulting metal distribution and consequently in the catalytic performance. For example, recently Xu et al. [133] compared the activity of Co/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by the typically used incipient wetness impregnation method and by Co ion exchange and found that the latter led to higher methane conversion and benzene formation rates. The former was only active for about two hours, and then deactivated quickly, whereas the ion exchanged Co catalyst maintained higher benzene formation rates over a period of ten hours. This was due to a better exchange of the Co species inside the zeolite channels via the ion exchange method, whereas by incipient wetness impregnation, unselective and less active Co clusters were formed on the external surface of the zeolite. Despite the observed improvement, the Co/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited an MDA activity that was inferior to that of Mo-based systems. Similar observations regarding the effect of metal location on the selectivity of products during methane conversion were made over Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts [134]. Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts made by means of incipient wetness impregnation caused a complete decomposition of CH4 to carbonaceous deposits, while the Ni sites anchored at the BAS via ion exchange method activated CH4 to the CHx species that later converted to aromatics. These results suggest that the method of addition of X metals via ion exchange may provide different locations and lead to different interactions with Mo and consequently different activity. Within the Mo-X literature, only three groups explored incorporation of the metal additives using the ion exchange method and/or CVD as a means to increase the dispersion of X inside the zeolite channels [90–93]. While the activity results obtained in these studies are not among the best (see activity data in Table 3), these studies indicate that catalyst synthesis by these methods is possible and further systematic work using these methods with varying metal loadings and compositions, along with rigorous structural characterization could lead to further insight regarding the structure-activity relationships. Another way in which the presence of X can affect Mo sites is by changing the properties of the Mo carbide structures. Kojima et al. [84] speculated that the presence of Pt modified the reduction and carburization pathway of the Mo oxide precursors, leading to formation of metastable α-MoC1-x, instead of the stable β-Mo2C phase that is usually formed after the reaction induction period. This metastable phase is usually very challenging and difficult to detect in these systems, given that usually it has been detected by XRD, and the intense ZSM-5 peaks usually overlap with a lot of the more intense Mo carbide peaks. Once again, the fact that this peak was detected by XRD indicates that the phase was formed on the external surface of the zeolite, but one cannot discard its formation inside the channels too. Whether Mo-Pd proximity plays a role in the mechanism of Mo carbide formation and preferential formation of α-MoC1-x versus β-Mo2C inside the channels would be an important question worth investigating. The observation of the effect of X on the type of Mo carbide formed, along with several trends observed by different groups point to the importance of performing an in-depth study of the induction period and/or pretreatment of the catalysts. Most of the groups that studied the Fe, Co, Ni additives [65–68,70,73,76–83] speculated that Mo alloys with these metals were responsible for preferential formation of carbon nanotubes on the external surface of the zeolites during reaction. Sridhar et al. [73,83] observed that pretreating Fe-, Co-, Ni-modified Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts under controlled reduction and carburization conditions to form carbide species ex situ led to a bigger enhancement in stability than if the carbides were formed in situ during the reaction induction period. These observations suggest that controlling the actual carburization conditions and understanding how the metals evolve from oxides in the as-prepared catalysts to active carbides after the reaction induction period will provide insight into the nature of the metal-carbon interactions and the role that they play in the reaction and deactivation pathways. Specifically, the presence of the additives could either modify the reducibility of the Mo species, leading to different degrees of reduction, or lead to formation of bimetallic carbides. Advanced in situ characterization techniques, including XAS, HR-TEM and HR-XRD measurements complemented with DFT calculations are required in order to gain more insight into the structural evolution of the metal sites and their capacity to activate methane. A tool that has been extremely underutilized in the MDA literature, and especially in the Mo-X/ZSM-5 literature is computation. Amongst the papers discussed in this review, only one of them, studying Pt-Sn/ZSM-5 [109] explored the combination of experimental studies with microkinetic modelling and DFT calculations. Given the elusive nature of the bimetallic species in being detected, especially under harsh reaction conditions, theoretical calculations remain an invaluable tool to better inform any experimental results, in particular for understanding the effect of the second metal on the electronic structure of the system and interactions of relevant species. Fundamental understanding built through these studies can then be used to identify particular catalytic systems of interest that can motivate further experimental directions. In conclusion, the use of additives in Mo/H-ZSM-5 systems enhances catalyst stability, however, in most cases the enhancement is only maintained for a short period of time, and catalysts eventually deactivate. A detailed understanding of the structural evolution and location of the metal sites is necessary in order to optimize further the multifunctional metal/zeolite catalysts for MDA. To achieve this understanding, future research directions should include synthesis procedures that allow for a controlled location of the metals; and monitoring and evaluating the evolution of the state and location of the metals throughout the entire catalytic cycle via in situ and Operando measurements. Despite the fact that multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite catalysts exhibit improved stability in MDA, the low one-pass conversion of the MDA reaction limits its deployment in the field. Therefore, coordinated studies combining the design of multifunctional catalyst formulations tailored specifically to operate in process intensified reactors, such as membrane reactors, fluidized bed reactors, or reactors involving co-feeds and coupling with chemical looping are required. Only by combining these studies will it be possible to achieve a system that can provide both a reasonable one-pass conversion of methane and benzene yield while maintaining a reasonable catalyst life that can enable MDA to become an attractive commercial route for production of aromatics. coredata.dc:description: The drastic rise in shale gas production has encouraged the quest for alternative uses of methane as a chemical feedstock in the manufacturing industry. While two-step syngas routes for methane valorization are deployed commercially, direct one-step routes for methane conversion are attracting much attention. As steam cracking installations have shifted from using oil-based naphtha to shale-based natural gas liquids, production of aromatics has dropped. Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a one-step reaction capable of valorizing methane to hydrogen and benzene. Challenges with the MDA reaction are two-fold: the reaction is thermodynamically limited with low one-pass methane conversion and even the best catalytic systems, Mo/zeolites, suffer rapid deactivation from coking. A catalyst design strategy to improve stability is the use of multifunctional Mo-X/zeolite systems where X is a dopant capable of modulating the stability. In this paper we provide a complete overview of the main Mo-X/zeolite systems used in MDA and critically draw connections among the different types of dopants (X) employed, as a function of the role they play in the reaction/deactivation pathway. We have also dedicated a section to emerging trends with non-Mo based catalysts. The goal of this review article is to establish a basis that will facilitate the identification of useful multifunctional catalytic systems, and recognize gaps in the knowledge of these systems that deserve more attention. Improving MDA systems to the point to which they can be commercially deployed requires a multifaceted approach that combines optimization of the designs of both the catalyst and the reactor configuration. We therefore also provide a brief overview of the most recent advances in process intensification strategies employed with different reactor configurations.
coredata.dc:title: A critical literature review of the advances in methane dehydroaromatization over multifunctional metal-promoted zeolite catalysts
